The American Journal of Computational Linguistics (ISSN 0362-613X) is published quarterly by the Associ- ation for Computational Linguistics.

variant.bodyText: Copyright C) 1982 by the Association for Computational Linguistics. The code and copyright notice appearing at the bottom of the first page of an article in this journal indicate the copyright owner's consent that copies of the article may be made for personal or internal use, or for the personal or internal use of specific clients. This consent is given on condition that the copier pay for copying beyond that permitted by Sections 107 and 108 of the U.S. Copyright Law. The per-copy fee for each article appears after the dollar sign and is to be paid through the Copyright Clearance Center, Inc. This con- sent does not apply to other kinds of copying, such as copying for general distribution, for advertising and pro- motional purposes, for creating new collective works, and for resale. Such permission requests and other permission inquiries should be addressed to the Manag- ing Editor at the address given above.
The Association for Computational Linguistics is an international professional society with membership open to any person or institution whose professional goals relate to computational linguistics.

variant.bodyText: Affiliations: The ACL is a constituent member of the American Federation of Information Processing Socie- ties, and is also associated with the International Com- mittee on Computational Linguistics. Subscriptions to the AJCL are available only through membership in the ACL. Each subscription includes both hard-copy and microfiche versions of the Journal. Annual membership dues are $15 for individuals and $30 for institutions. Joint memberships for couples are available for $20, but provide only one subscription. Postage: The AJCL is normally mailed bulk-rate. First class mailing is available in North America for an addi- tional annual charge of $6. Air-printed mailing is availa- ble overseas for an additional annual charge of $12. Back issues of the AJCL may be ordered at annual rates of $15 for individuals and $30 for institutions. The first five volumes (1974-1978) are available only on micro- fiche; Volumes 6 and 7 (1980 and 1981) are available in both hard-copy and microfiche form; first class mailing is an additional $6, and air-printed mailing is an addi- tional $12. The AJCL was not published during 1979. Payments for dues or back issues should be sent to the ACL Secretary-Treasurer at the address given above. Checks should be made out to the Association for Com- putational Linguistics (or to ACL) and should be payable in U.S. dollars. There is an additional $2 charge for bank processing costs for checks that are not drawn on U.S. banks. Address changes should be sent to the ACL Secretary-Treasurer at the address given above. A Note from the Editor: This issue of the American Journal of Computational Linguistics (AJCL) is the first of 1982 to appear, although the fourth quarter issue of 1981 was distributed earlier this year. When we took over as editors pro tern., we inherited a number of papers in the process of being reviewed by referees or being revised by authors, but no papers in final form awaiting publication. The process of keeping after referees to turn in their reviews, encouraging authors of conditionally accepted papers to make necessary revisions, and producing the final version of revised papers in camera-ready form has proved to be much more tortuous and time-consuming than we anticipated. Consequently, this first issue of 1982 is coming out in October. Prospects for future issues are brighter. We now have in hand the proceedings of the workshop on "Applied Computational Linguistics in Perspective", jointly organized by NRL, ACL, and NSF and funded by ONR, which took place June 26-27, 1981, at Stanford University. We also have a number of accepted papers being revised by their authors. Consequently, it is expected that the April-June issue will follow close on the heels of this one. We are happy to report that our interim editorship is over, and that James Allen of the University of Rochester will be taking over on a permanent basis starting with the third issue of 1982. Future contributions should be sent to him at the address given on the inside back cover. It is clear that one or possibly two issues of 1982 will have to appear in 1983. Our goal is to limit this to the last issue of 1982, and with the cooperation of reviewers and authors, this should be possible. We will delay the thanks we owe to everyone who has assisted us until the next and (for us) final issue. In the meantime, we would like to thank you readers for your patience, and to encourage you to hang in there; more issues are on the way.
variant.note: F. J. Damerau and S. R. Petrick, Editors Pro Tem.
American Journal of Computational Linguistics Volume 8, Number 1 January-March 1982
